answers.answer: Your peroxidase (TPOab) is a thyroid antibody test.  If it is elevated, which it is, it indicates an autoimmune condition.  This can be Grave's disease (hyper) or Hashi's (hypo).Besides the enlarged thyroid, what are your symptoms?Your bloodwork looks hyper.  FT3 and FT4 are above range, and TSH is very low.  However, your uptake scan is a bit contradictory, since, as you say, it indicates very low thyroid activity.Were the bloodwork and scans done at the same time?

It's a relief to know that you see somewhat contradictory results, too.The blood draw was last Sunday and the scan was done Tuesday/Wednesday.My thyroid is enlarged and also painful.  Some days are better than others but I'm taking ibuprofen pretty regularly.As for other symptoms, they seem to be all over the place, too.  My fingernails have become brittle, I'm really tired sometimes, my heart races sometimes, my thinking is slow/confused sometimes; I haven't lost or gained weight; I can be quite moody (although at age 49 there are plenty of hormones contributing to that!).My thyroid is nowhere near as sore and swollen as it was a month ago when it was at its worst.  The inside of my throat had two raw patches that made it hard to swallow and I had to take ibuprofen religiously or the pain was too much.  Now my thyroid is about 1/3 the size it was then except for the front.  Now that part is so swollen that I'm hoarse all the time.What do you think?

Well, I'm looking at 59 at my next birthday (good-bye cushion between me and the big six-oh).  The hormones may have calmed down, but I'm not sure that's an improvement!  Not feeling well can make you pretty moody, too.I have to say that if I just looked at your bloodwork, I'd say Grave's without thinking twice...FT3 and FT4 are over the top, TSH is virtually non-existent, TPOab positive.  It all fits.  I've been trying to fit the uptake results in with this, and I just can't.  You've even sent me back to the internet to see if I can find anything similar...no luck there, either.  Is there any possibility that something affected the scan results?  Meds or supplements?  Iodine consumption?  High iodine foods?  Big, big fan of sushi?!As long as the swelling is not affecting your breathing or swallowing, I don't think it's a problem to wait until the 9th.  That's just a week from Monday, and it would probably be difficult to get anything sooner.  Your hoarseness is most likely due to the enlargement pressing on the laryngeal nerve, which causes voice changes.It's also possible that you are in a hyper phase of Hashi's.  Although this is ultimately a hypothyroid condition, there is often an initial hyper phase (usually short lived...several days).  In addition, some types of nodules (most of us with Hashi's have nodules) can "leak" rather than secrete hormones into the bloodstream.  This happens in a pretty uncontrolled manner and can cause swings from hypo to hyper.Sorry I can't offer more...would love an update after you've seen the endo to see what he has to say.I'm going to PM someone who I know knows a lot about Grave's and ask her to take a look at this thread.  Maybe she'll be more familiar with your scenario.
At long last, my appointment with an endocrinologist is tomorrow morning.  Are there any specific questions that I should ask him -- given my test results?  Any other advice is most welcome!

I'd definitely ask him to explain what appears to be the contradiction between bloodwork and the scan (I'm sure this is probably at the top of your list, anyway.)  Beyond that, I'm afraid I can't suggest a lot.  I'm assuming he's going to start you on anti-thyroid meds.  Those will get your FT3 and FT4 down some and give you time to research and decide whether or not you want to pursue a more permanent solution.  I'm very curious to hear what he has to say.  Best of luck at your appointment...hope all your questions are answered.

Good news. :)The endo says that I'm definitely hyperthyroid and that while there are antibodies in my blood, that's common in people with thyroiditis.  My thyroid will heal on its own and he's putting me on a low dose of a beta blocker to help with symptoms (racing heart, shaking hands, etc).  Although I could get thyroiditis again, right now it's not likely.  If it does come back, the odds of it becoming Hashi's are pretty good.So, for now I am relieved.  Good, compassionate care -- and some answers!

Thanks for the update.  Once your doctor diagnosed thyroiditis and said your thyroid would heal on its own, I realized he was talking about DeQuervain's thyroiditis.  I went tohttp://endocrineweb.com/thyroiditis.html.Very interesting...I had researched DeQuervain's a long time ago because I thought that's what I might have at first (before being diagnosed with Hashi's).  It was fascinating to get a refresher course.I'm on a beta blocker because I have a congenital heart defect that predisposes me to tachycardia, and my Levoxyl really exacerbates the tachy.  The BBs help a lot with that.Are you following up with further testing in the next few months?

Yes, I have blood tests scheduled in two weeks, then once a month after that for a while.  They expect me to go hypo at some point.Thanks for the info on DeQuervain's.  I had no idea there was such a thing.I took the beta blocker for the first time yesterday but will be calling the endo's office later today.  It caused the worst diarrhea I've ever had in my life.  About 12 hours after taking it, I started running to the bathroom and having horrible cramps.  That lasted about four hours.  My dad was on a beta blocker for a while and it did the same thing to him.  Wow.You're a fountain of information.  Thanks so much.  :)

It's good to hear that they're keeping on top of it with further testing...excellent.You might ask your endo to try a different BB - there are several.  I never had any problem when I started BBs, but I was so miserable with the tachycardia from the Levoxyl that I'd have put up with about anything if it relieved that (and it did, and immediately).Keep us updated on how you go...DeQuervain's is quite rare, so it's really interesting to get some first-hand information on how it unfolds.I bet you're feeling better just knowing what's going on...

I DO feel a lot better just knowing what's going on.Speaking of rare . . . I have late onset Type 1 diabetes, too.  No family history of ANY diabetes.  Just a genetic fluke, I guess.I am one of the chosen few.  :DI'll keep you posted.

question: I finally got the test results from a blood draw on October 25.  Now I'm more confused than before -- and my family practice doc who ordered the tests says that I should just wait until I see an endo on Nov. 9 and has no treatment plan for me.  My thyroid has been enlarged and painful for about six weeks.  It's smaller now but has started to swell in the very front causing me to be hoarse.Please help me figure out what MIGHT be going on.  I have Type 1 diabetes and am concerned that it might be another autoimmune problem.  Mostly, I'd love to have someone give me the "big picture" view of what's going on -- before November 9!Test ResultsTSH less than 0.02 (reference range .40 to 4.7)Free T3  7.2 (reference range 2.8 to 5.3)Free T4 3.1 (reference range .7 to 1.9)Thyroid stimulating immunoglob less than 1.0 (reference 0 to 1.3)Thyroperoxidase 232.6 (reference range 0 to 8.9)Thyroglobulin 2.7 (reference range 0 to 3.9)I also had a thyroid uptake and scan.  The results showed very low thyroid activity:Six hours:  .7% (reference range 4 to 20%)24 hours:  .3% (reference range 6 to 32%)Your thoughts?  Advice?  Do I need to see an endo sooner?  In a nutshell -- how serious it is?Thanks so much.Janet
title: Hyper, hypo or just what?
